intro: Galium sylvestre f. hirtum, commonly known as hairy wood-creepers, is a variant of the wood-creepers, a group of flowering plants in the Rubiaceae family. It is characterized by its erect, hairy stems and small, clustered white flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and often covered with fine hairs, contributing to its distinctive appearance. This subspecies is valued for its ornamental qualities and ecological role in supporting local insect populations.
